Title: 51% Attack
Description: An attack on blockchain by a group of miners controlling more than 50% of network hash rate

Title: gm Good Morning
Description: gm is the short form writing for good morning. Used extensively within the crypto community where individuals greet each other casually. On the other hand, good night (gn) is used when people sign off for the day.

Title: Address Delegation
Description: Delegation of a wallet's stake to a Super Staker

Title: Airdrop
Description: A way to promote cryptocurrencies by sending some free tokens to traders

Title: Algorithm
Description: Algorithm is a set of rules to follow to solve a problem or conduct a task.

Title: Algorithmic Stablecoin
Description: Algorithmic stablecoins are tokens pegged to a fiat currency which is usually the US dollar, purely through software and specific conditions.

Title: All-Time-High (ATH)
Description: The highest point (in price, in market capitalization) that a cryptocurrency has been in history.

Title: All-Time-Low (ATL)
Description: The lowest point (in price, in market capitalization) that a cryptocurrency has been in history.

Title: Altcoin
Description: Coins althernative to Bitcoin

Title: Application Programming Interface (API)
Description: It is a software that acts like an intermediary or a bridge that lets two applications talk to each other. It is the one that lets applications, data and devices interact.

Title: Application-Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC)
Description: Refers to specialized computers that are made to do a very specific task (eg. calculate hashes for Bitcoin's Proof-of-Work)

Title: Arbitrage
Description: A strategy where investors buy a currency in a market and sell it at a higher price in another market to gain profit.

Title: ASIC Resistant
Description: A term used to describe cryptocurrency proof-of-work protocols that are resistant to Application-Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC), by packing in various parameters that make it difficult for ASICs to have a competitive edge against consumer hardwares.

Title: Ask Me Anything (AMA)
Description: Ask me anything refers to actions where individuals of certain profession (eg. fireman, nurse, journalists) or company (eg. CEO of Tesla) conduct a session for users to ask them questions.

Title: Atomic SWAP
Description: Atomic Swap refers to the exchange of cryptocurrencies that operate in different block chains without intermediaries.

Title: Automatic Replay Protection
Description: Automatic Replay Protection refers to the upgrade implemented by Bitcoin Cash to stop the loss of funds from exchanges through replay attacks.

Title: Bagholder
Description: A person who is holding a large quantity of cryptocurrency which is declining in value or becoming worthless

Title: Bakkt
Description: Bakkt is a company developed by the Intercontinental Exchange (ICE), owner of the New York Stock Exchange. It specializes in Futures/Options contracts for cryptocurrencies.

Title: Batch Auction
Description: A Batch Auction distributes an amount of tokens to users that is proportional to their contribution to the pool.

Title: Bearish
Description: A term used to indicate negative sentiment towards the market or an asset, where investors believe that there will be downward price movement.

Title: Bear Market
Description: Contrary to bull market, it indicates the direction of the market going for downward trend.

Title: Bitcoin ATM
Description: A machine from which you can buy or sell Bitcoin. Typically also offers different types of cryptocurrencies.

Title: Bitcoin Evangelist
Description: Individuals who are passionate about Bitcoin, and are dedicated in spreading knowlege about Bitcoin

Title: Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP)
Description: Refers to improvement proposals for Bitcoin, used to introduce features or any updates on the Bitcoin network.

Title: BitLicense
Description: Refers to the business license issued by the New York State Department of Financial Services (NYSDFS) to companies dealing with Cryptocurrencies (subject to certain exceptions) in New York.

Title: Block
Description: In the context of blockchain, block refers to the collection of transactional data or information that are bundled together in a predetermined size.

Title: Blockchain
Description: In Bitcoin's case, blockchain describes its decentralized, public ledger which contains transactional information.

Title: Block Confirmation
Description: Refers to the number of confirmation a particular block has. Each block ahead of the referenced block adds one block confirmation to it.

Title: Block Explorer
Description: Application or websites which display information such as status of transactions or data contained in a block of a given public blockchain network.

Title: Block Height
Description: A number that is used to indicated the position of a particular block within a blockchain

Title: Block Reward
Description: One of the mechanisms built into a blockchain to incentivize validators

Title: Bloodbath
Description: In context of trading, the term bloodbath is commonly used to describe a market which is on a downtrend with many assets suffering from value depreciation.

Title: Bots
Description: Refers to software or programmes that automatically trade based on preset behaviours.

Title: Bounty
Description: Public tasks available for anyone for a reward

Title: BUIDL
Description: An advice for investors to contribute new projects on blockchain rather than holding cryptocurrencies and waiting for the price to increase

Title: Bullish
Description: A term used to indicate positive sentiment towards the market or an asset, where investors believe that there will be upward price movement.

Title: Bull Market
Description: A bull market indicates the direction of the market going in an upward trend.

Title: Burned Tokens
Description: Tokens which have been sent to addresses whose private key are not known, effectively becoming unusable.

Title: Buy/Sell Tax
Description: On-chain buy or sell tax rate where a percentage of the tokens bought/sold will be transferred to a set address.

Title: Buy the F***in Dip (BTFD)
Description: An encouraging rally by asset/cryptocurrency supporters to buy during a price decline

Title: Buy Wall
Description: Anomalously large buy order(s) at a single price point that reflects as a "wall" in the order book.

Title: Byzantine Fault
Description: A byzantine fault is where an error has occured, yet a computer system does not know due which component/what failed to the lack of information and continues to iterate on a given instruction.

Title: Byzantine Generals� Problem
Description: A term used to describe the situation a single strategy which requires consensus from all members within a group who cannot be trusted or verified

Title: Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC)
Description: It is a digital fiat currency issued by the central banks, contrary to cryptocurrency that issued by non-legislative party.

Title: Centralized
Description: An organization structure wherein a small handful of actors have control over the entire network.

Title: Central Ledger
Description: Central data repository of a company or bank

Title: Circulating Supply
Description: An approximation of the number of coins or tokens that are currently not locked and available for public transactions.

Title: Cloud Mining
Description: Mining on blockchains through rented processing power rented from companies that host the physical equipment.

Title: Cold Storage
Description: Offline storage of cryptocurrencies which is arguably safer as they also require physical access (eg. hardware wallet, paper wallets)

Title: Cold Wallet
Description: Wallets that are offline and require physical access to certain devices (eg. hardware wallet, paper wallets)

Title: Collateralized Debt Obligation (CDO)
Description: A collateralized debt obligation (CDO) is a form of derivative in which the value is generated from another underlying asset, and is sold to institutional investors.

Title: Composability
Description: Composability refers to the ability to combine different components of a software stack.

Title: Consensus
Description: Consensus is achieved in a blockchain system when all participants agree on the content of the next block that will be added onto the blockchain.

Title: Crowdsale
Description: This type of auction has a fixed price per token that is sold on a first-come-first-serve basis.

Title: Crypto Bubble
Description: It is a speculation in the cryptocurrencies and the price of cryptocurrencies would go extremely high before the bubble bursts.

Title: Cryptocurrency
Description: A form of digital currency that utilizes cryptographic protocols to record ownership and prevent counterfeiting

Title: Cryptocurrency Act of 2020
Description: The Cryptocurrency Act of 2020 is a bill which aims to clarify which federal agencies would regulate which type of crypto assets.

Title: Cryptography
Description: A discipline or field of study which practices using cryptography to convert human-readable information that can only be deciphered by individuals who have the knowledge to.

Title: Custody
Description: Protective care or guardianship of an asset.

Title: Daily Active Addresses (DAA)
Description: On a blockchain, users interact with one another through their addresses, and daily active addresses (DAA) refers to the number of addresses which fulfills the defined activity parameter on a given blockchain.

Title: Dead Cat Bounce
Description: Price rally that is short lived after a prolonged decline. Price charts will show a recovery in anticipation of a market turnaround only to decline further.

Title: Decentralized
Description: A system where there are no centralized points of failure or organization with no central authority figure.

Title: Decentralized Applications (dApps)
Description: Applications that run on decentralized peer-to-peer networks such as Ethereum.

Title: Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO)
Description: Open source and decentralized systems that do not require centralized operators or controllers.

Title: Decentralized Finance (DeFi)
Description: Decentralized Finance (DeFi) refers to the movement of building decentralized financial applications that have no central authority and is censorship free.

Title: Decryption
Description: The process of decrypting data that was previously encrypted (made unreable) back to a readable form.

Title: Degen
Description: Cryptotrading without Due Diligence and research - basically gambling

Title: Delegated Proof-of-Stake (dPOS)
Description: A consensus mechanism where selected members of a network are voted as delegates to validate transactions and produce blocks on a blockchain.

Title: Derivatives
Description: A financial instrument which derives its value from the performance of an underlying asset or index (eg. gold, crude oil)

Title: Derivatives Market
Description: A market for derivatives which are instruments such as futures or options whose value is derived from an underlying asset.

Title: Difficulty
Description: A relative measure on how difficult it is to correctly guess a new block

Title: Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG)
Description: Directed acyclic graphs refers to a data structure that is built in one single direction, yet branches out and never repeats.

Title: Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) Attack
Description: A common cyber-attack tactic where a perpetrator diverts large amounts of traffic towards a particular network or service in an effort to disrupt normal services.

Title: Distributed Ledger
Description: Ledgers whose data is stored and synced across a network of nodes.

Title: Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT)
Description: Describes the technology that enables distributed ledger.

Title: Dominance
Description: Typically refers to Bitcoins' market capitalization dominance.

Title: Double Spending
Description: Double spending refers to the act of spending digital currencies twice. This is most commonly applied on crypto exchanges by unscrupulous actors.

Title: Do Your Own Research (DYOR)
Description: An advice for investors to do their own research on the coins they wanted to invest in

Title: Dump
Description: A common term used to describe downward market movement, or to describe the action of selling an individuals holdings.

Title: Dusting Attack
Description: A new form of malicious activity in which hackers and scammers attempt to undermine the privacy of cryptocurrency users by sending little amounts of money to their wallets.

Title: Dutch Auction
Description: A Dutch Auction, also know as an "inverted" auction, starts off with high asking price that decays over time until a pre-determined floor price.

Title: EIP (Ethereum Improvement Proposal)
Description: Refers to improvement proposals for Ethereum, used to introduce features or any updates on the Ethereum network.

Title: Emission
Description: The speed/rate at which new coins are minted and released as dictated by the protocols written.

Title: Encryption
Description: In cryptography, encryption is a process of encoding information the original form of information called plaintext via an algorithm called cipher. The encrypted message is now called ciphertext. Only authorized parties can decipher the ciphertext and convert back it to the original plaintext.

Title: Enterprise Ethereum Alliance (EEA)
Description: Enterprise Ethereum Alliance is made up for a group of Ethereum developers, corporations as well as startups who are collaborating to find ways to use Ethereum for business applications.

Title: ERC-1155
Description: ERC-1155 token standard allows each token ID to represent both non-fungible (NFTs) and fungible tokens which may have their metadata, token supply and other attributes.

Title: ERC-20
Description: ERC-20 is one of the most widely used token standards in Ethereum to create fungible, exchangeable tokens.

Title: ERC-721
Description: ERC-721 is one of the most widely used token standards in Ethereum to create non-fungible, exchangeable tokens.

Title: Ethereum Name Service (ENS)
Description: Ethereum Name Service (ENS) is a look-up service that allows Ethereum users to find websites or send and receive funds via simple names.

Title: Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM)
Description: Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) is the environment in which all smart contracts are executed.

Title: Exchange Traded Fund (ETF)
Description: An exchange-traded fund (ETF) is a form of security that tracks a collection of securites such as stocks, bonds, index or cryptocurrency but tradeable like a single stock.

Title: Explain Like I'm Five (ELI5)
Description: To explain in such simple terms that even a five-year-old would be able to understand it.

Title: Externally Owned Accounts (EOA)
Description: Externally owned accounts (EOAs) are accounts that are controlled by a private key and have no coding associated with them.

Title: Faucet
Description: A faucet usually represents a site or app where a user can navigate to for small rewards repeated over time.

Title: Fear of Missing Out (FOMO)
Description:
Refers to the feeling of apprehension for missing out on a potentially profitable investment opportunity and regretting it later.
Generally an expression describing investors' fear of missing out the good timing of buying cryptocurrencies that could eventually be profitable

Title: Fear, Uncertainty and Doubt (FUD)
Description: A strategy to dissuade people from buying a particular cryptocurrency by spreading false information

Title: Fiat-Pegged Cryptocurrency
Description: Cryptocurrencies are pegged to an underlying asset.

Title: Flappening
Description: Flappening is a term used to describe Litecoin growing bigger and becoming more valuable than Bitcoin Cash (BCH). It is spawned from the term Flippening (used when another crypto overtakes Bitcoin).

Title: Frontrun
Description: To intercept a particularly large AMM buy order for the purpose of purchasing an reselling the assets back to the buyer before the order transaction is mind on the blockchain.

Title: Full Node
Description: Full Nodes are computers that verify the set of rules that are built into the protocols of a given cryptocurrency.

Title: Full Pay-Per-Share (FPPS)
Description: FPPS is quite similar to PPS; the only difference is that the pool will additionally pay a transaction fee incentive if the block is identified. FPPS is the same as PPS+.

Title: Futures
Description: An agreement between two counterparties that obligates them to transact in the future based on the contract terms set.

Title: Gas
Description: A unit of measurement of the computational effort in conducting transactions or smart contracts on Ethereum blockchain.

Title: Gas Limit
Description: A term refers to the maximum amount of units of gas user's willingness to spend on a transaction on Ethereum blockchain.

Title: Gas Price
Description: A term refers to the amount of price user is willing to pay for a transaction on Ethereum blockchain.

Title: Genesis Block
Description: It is the first block of data that is processed and validated to form a new blockchain, typically called as 'block 0' or 'block 1'.

Title: Goblin Town
Description: A term used to describe the market's persistent downtrend, synonymous with "bear market".

Title: Golden Cross
Description: It is a bullish signal in technical candlestick pattern by comparing two lines of short-term moving average and long-term average. It is a golden cross when the short term moving average broke its long-term moving average.

Title: Graphical Processing Unit (GPU)
Description: They are chips dedicated to graphics processing or floating point operations, allowing to lighten the workload of the processors during applications usage such as video games.

Title: Gwei
Description: The monetary domination of gas, involving Ether

Title: Halving
Description: Event that serves to reduce in half the reward of the Proof-of-Work miners that operate in the blockchain network.

Title: Hard cap
Description: The maximum amount that an ICO will be raising.

Title: Hard Fork
Description: It is a permanent divergence of a blockchain into two blockhains. The original blockchain does not recognize the new version.

Title: Hash
Description: A hash function is an output code (unique and alphanumeric) that we obtain from an input string,

Title: Hashgraph
Description: Hashgraph is a distributed ledger system that has been compared to the blockchain idea as a continuation or successor.

Title: Hashrate
Description: Total processing power of a blockchain or what is the same, are the amount of hash values that can be made in a period of time.

Title: Hey Hey Hey
Description: A term made popular by Carlos Matos who was the spokesperson for the Bitconnect Ponzi. He used it frequently during Bitconnect events to rile up the crowd.

Title: HODL
Description:
A crypto slang of saying holding the assets rather than selling it.
A crypto slang encouraging investors to hold on to their assets rather than selling it.

Title: Hot Wallet
Description: It is a tool that store your cryptocurrencies and always connected to internet

Title: Hybrid PoW/PoS
Description: It is the allowance for both Proof-of-Stake and Proof-of-Work distribution consensus to work on the same network.

Title: Hyperledger (Hyperledger Foundation)
Description: Hyperledger is an open source collaborative effort to create blockchain technologies hosted by The Linux Foundation since 2016.

Title: IEO
Description: Initial Exchange Offering (IEO) is a spin-off of Initial Coin Offering (ICO), where the sale of tokens are conducted on an exchange rather than by the coin team themselves.

Title: Immutable
Description: A property characterized by inability to be change and stays unchanged over time.

Title: Impermanent Loss
Description: Temporary loss of funds due to volatility leading to divergence in price between token pairs provided by liquidity providers.

Title: Initial Coin Offering (ICO)
Description: Initial Coin Offering (ICO) is the equivalent of Initial Public Offering (IPO), where a company/cryptocurrency venture raises funds through crowd sales.

Title: Internet of Things (IoT)
Description: It is a system that lets any devices that are connected to internet to comunicate with each other without human-to-human or human-to-devices interactions.

Title: Interoperability
Description: Interoperability refers to the property of product/systems that are able to work with products/systems that are different without any restrictions.

Title: InterPlanetary File System (IPFS)
Description: The InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) is a peer-to-peer network and distributed file system protocol for storing and transferring data.

Title: IPO
Description: Initial Public Offering (IPO) refers to the process where a public company offers newly issued shares to the public and as a result raise capital from public investors.

Title: Kimchi Premium
Description: The kimchi premium is the price difference between South Korean exchanges and other global exchanges for bitcoin.

Title: KYC (Know Your Customer)
Description: KYC stands for "Know Your Customer", a process for business entities are required to verify its clients and assessing them.

Title: Ledger
Description: A record of financial transactions that cannot be changed, only appended with new transactions.

Title: Leverage
Description: It is an investment strategy to gain potential return of the investment by borrowing the money

Title: Lightning Network
Description: It is the "second layer" or an off-chain of payment protocol that operates on top of a blockchain. Payments on this network do not need block confirmation and it will be instant.

Title: Limit Order / Limit Buy / Limit Sell
Description: Orders placed by traders to buy or sell a cryptocurrency when a certain price is reached

Title: Liquidity
Description: How easily a cryptocurrency can be bought and sold without impacting the overall market price.

Title: Liquid Proof of Stake (LPoS)
Description: A proof of stake consensus mechanism by Tezos that slightly differs from Delegated Proof of Stake.

Title: Mainnet
Description: It is the main network of Bitcoin, where the transactions of this cryptocurrency are registered and take place.

Title: Margin Call
Description: Margin call takes place when investor's margin account falls below the required amount to stay afloat.

Title: Margin Trading
Description: It is a way of investing by borrowing money from a broker (or in crypto, an exchange or platform) to trade

Title: Market capitalization (market cap)
Description: In Crypto, market cap is measured by multiplication of the circulating supply of tokens or currency and its current price

Title: Market Maker
Description: Participant of the market who creates buy and orders

Title: Market Order / Market Buy / Market Sell
Description: A market order is a buy or sell order of stocks or cryptocurrency at the best price available in the current market as soon as possible.

Title: Market Taker
Description: Participant of the market who buys and sells from currently existing orders

Title: Masternodes
Description: Computers that are responsible for processing blockchain transactions and receive a reward when a block is mined.

Title: Mempool
Description: It is the abbreviation of Memory Pool. Set of unconfirmed transactions in a blockchain

Title: Merkle Tree
Description: A Merkle tree is also known as a hash tree in cryptography. It is a tree where every lead node is labelled with cryptographic hash of a data block, and every non-leaf node is labelled with the hash of the labels of its child nodes. It is used to verify of data stored within it and transferable in and between computers.

Title: Metaverse
Description: The Metaverse is a virtual space where users are able to interact with each other in a computer generated environment.

Title: MicroBitcoin (uBTC)
Description: One millionth of a bitcoin or 0.000001 of a bitcoin. Microbitcoin is the abbreviation of uBTC and often misunderstood as the fork of Bitcoin.

Title: Microtransaction
Description: Microtransaction is a system that made very small payments possible in buying the common digital goods and services, such as purchasing items in a game.

Title: Mineable
Description: A cryptocurrency is said to be "mineable" when it has the system thrugh which miners can be rewarded with newly-created cryptocurrencies for creating blocks.

Title: Miners
Description: Contributors to a blockchain taking part in the process of mining.

Title: Mining
Description: It is the process of the miners verify and adding transaction recors into a block.

Title: Mining Contract
Description: Another term for cloud mining, where users can rent or invest in mining capacity online.

Title: Mining Pool
Description: Combination of resources of several miners to obtain a higher mining power and thus achieve greater rewards for the opening of blocks.

Title: Mining Reward
Description: The reward resulting from contributing computing resources to process transactions

Title: Mining Rig
Description: A dedicated hardware to mine

Title: Mnemonic Phrase
Description: A mnemonic phrase (also known as mnemonic seed, or seed phrase) is a list of words used in sequence to access or restore your cryptocurrency assets.

Title: Mnemonics
Description: Mnemonics are memory aids with a system such as letters or associations that help in recall. *see Mnemonic Phrase.

Title: Money Printer Go Brrr
Description: A meme made to describe the US Fed printing excessive amount of money to support the traditional financial market to avert the stock market crash during the COVID-19 coronavirus pandemic.

Title: Moon
Description: Moon" or "To the moon" is a crypto slang that describes an exclamation when the cryptocurrencies prices are rising and when it hit the peak, the coin is said to be "mooning".

Title: Mt. Gox
Description: Mtgox or Mt. Gox was one of the first websites where users could take part in fiat-to-bitcoin exchange (and vice versa).

Title: Multisignal (multi-signature)
Description: They are wallets that require more than one key for transactions to be authorized.

Title: Node
Description: Within the blockchain network, the nodes are computers that connect to the network and have an updated copy of the blockchain

Title: Nonce
Description: Abbreviation for �number only used once� It is of vital importance next to the hash in the verification of data from the Bitcoin blockchain network.

Title: Non-custodial
Description: It is a decentralized type-of-wallet, where the users owns its private keys.

Title: Non-Fungible Tokens (NFT)
Description: They are collectible elements within the Ethereum blockchain under ERC-721, where each token refers to a single element with a certain value

Title: Off-chain
Description: It refers to transactions occuring outside the blockchain and executed instantly.

Title: Offline Staking
Description: Staking without needing to be connected to the blockchain

Title: Open/Close
Description: The price at which a cryptocurrency opens at a time period, for example at the start of the day; the price at which a cryptocurrency closes at a time period, for example at the end of the day.

Title: Open Source
Description: Open-source software is a type of software released under a license in which the copyright holder grants users the rights to study, change, and distribute the software to anyone and for any purpose.

Title: Option
Description: It is a financial instruments that refers to a contract offers the buyer the right to buy or sell an underlying assets at a specified price and time.

Title: Oracles
Description: In the context of crypto, oracles refers to services which verify real-world and provide data to blockchains/smart contracts.

Title: Order Book
Description: An electronic list of all buy and sell orders in an exchange

Title: Over The Counter (OTC)
Description: It refers to the process that cryptocurrencies are being traded outside exchange and it is done directly between two parties

Title: Pay-Per-Last N Shares (PPLNS)
Description: PPLNS system only pays miners after the pool has discovered the block. This means you'll only be compensated once the block has been discovered.

Title: Pay-Per-Share (PPS)
Description: You are compensated for each valid share that you contribute. Each share is worth a set amount of cryptocurrency that may be mined.

Title: Peer to Peer
Description: A communication protocol that does not require a central hub

Title: Permissioned Blockchain
Description: It is a private blockchain where the nodes must be previously authorized by a central entity.

Title: Ponzi Scheme
Description: A Ponzi scheme is also referred to as pyramid scheme, and typically takes the form of an investment scheme which pays existing investors with funds collected from new investors.

Title: Portfolio
Description: A portfolio consists all of your current crypto holdings in one place.

Title: Pre-sale
Description: A typically exclusive token sale event preceding a public ICO

Title: Privacy Coins
Description: Cryptocurrencies that are designed with transaction anonimity and user privacy in mind.

Title: Private Keys
Description: The alphanumeric string which allows transactions from the cryptocurrency address

Title: Proof-of-Authority (PoA)
Description: A consensus algorithm that asigns block validation queue based on identity and reputation.

Title: Proof-of-Burn (PoB)
Description: A consensus algorthm that assigns block validation queue based on the coins/token burned by the validator.

Title: Proof-of-Developer (PoD)
Description: A concept of identifying the developers of a project as a means of vouching reputation for a project

Title: Proof of Stake (PoS)
Description: A consensus algorthm that assigns block validation queue based on the coins/token locked in by the validator.

Title: Proof of Work (PoW)
Description: A consensus algorithm in which a block is validated via mathematical hashing

Title: Protocol
Description: The set of rules in a network in which participating members comply to allow proper communication.

Title: Public Blockchain
Description: An open sourced blockchain where participation is public and permissionless

Title: Public Keys
Description: The alphanumeric string which serves as a public receiving address in cryptocurrencies.

Title: Pump and Dump Scheme
Description: A market manipulation method to drive up the price of an asset before profiting by driving it back down.

Title: QR Code
Description: Abbreviation "Quick Response Code", QR code is a machine readable optical label that stores up to 3Kb of data

Title: Reddit r/CryptoCurrency Moon
Description: Moons are a new way for people to be rewarded for their contributions to r/CryptoCurrency

Title: REKT
Description: A shorthand slang for �wrecked�, typically describes bad trades that results in losses.

Title: Relative Strength Index (RSI)
Description: Relative Strength Index (RSI) is a popular technical indicator used to analyse financial markets. By charting the current and historical closing prices to evaluate overbought/oversold conditions, RSI oscillates between 0 - 100, with <30 indicating oversold and >70 indicating overbought.

Title: Replay Attack
Description: A replay attack is a form of network attack when valid data transmission is fraudulently intercepted, then delayed or resent to mislead the receiver into doing what the hacker wants.

Title: Ring Signature
Description: A type of digital signature performed in a group where it becomes impossible to determine which member's key in the group were used for the digital signature.

Title: ROI
Description: Short for �Return on Investment�, the ratio between the net profit and cost of investing.

Title: Rug Pull
Description: Sudden removal of liquidity which typically leads to asset prices crashing from the lack of liquidity to absorb buy/sells.

Title: Salt (cryptography)
Description: In cryptography, a salt is the additional random input that is added to password or passphrase to make the password hash unique. It prevents from the hashed output password to be cracked so easily by the hacker.

Title: Satoshi
Description: A unit measure for the smallest divisible unit of a bitcoin. 1 bitcoin is equal to 100 Million Satoshi.

Title: Satoshi Nakamoto
Description: The pseudoym used in publishing the Bitcoin Whitepaper. Identity is unknown.

Title: Scrypt
Description: one of the hashing algoritm used in proof-of-work protocol, scrypt requires more memory in order to performing mining functions

Title: Second-Layer Solutions
Description: Secondary network or framework built atop an existing blockchain to address transaction speed and scalability issues.

Title: Secure Asset Fund for Users (SAFU)
Description: A feature created by Binance which contains reserve funds that can be used to reimburse users in case of a catastrophic event (eg. exchange hack)

Title: Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)
Description: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, an independant agency of the US Federal government which oversees federal securities laws, proposing securities rules, and regulating the securities industry.

Title: Seed
Description: A value used to initiate generation of pseudorandom number, ususally a string of 12 commen English words.

Title: Segregated Witness (SegWit)
Description: A soft fork implementation to change the Bitcoin Protocol's transaction format to address Bitcoin's scalability issues whilst introducing new features.

Title: Sell wall
Description: Anomalously large sell order(s) at a single price point that reflects as a "wall" in the order book.

Title: SHA-256
Description: Abbreviation of "Secure Hashing Algoritm - 256", SHA-256 is part of the SHA2 that allows one-way hashing of any data into a 64 character string.

Title: Sharding
Description: A form of database partitioning which breaks up data into smaller segments.

Title: Shilling
Description: One who poses as a enthsiastic customer to swindle others as a form of covert advestising.

Title: Shitcoin
Description: A coin with no obvious potential value or usage.

Title: Side Chain
Description: A separate blockchain ledger that runs parallel with the primary blockchain.

Title: Sim Swapping
Description: It is a tactic where hacker overtake the mobile phone to exploit the two-factor authentication and two-step verification.

Title: Smart contracts
Description: Self executing contracts on the blockchain without needing human executors or notary.

Title: Soft Cap
Description: Targeted fund raising limit of an ICO

Title: Soft Fork
Description: A backward-compatible update to a decentralized blockchain protocol.

Title: Software Development Kit (SDK)
Description: It is a collection of software development tools in one package installation. It is designed to help developing applications for a specific device or operating system (OS).

Title: Solidity
Description: Object oriented programming languaged used in various smart contract blockchains.

Title: Solo Staker
Description: A Qtum PoS miner using their own coins for staking. Qtum blockchain launched with Solo Stakers and will continue to have this available after offline staking launches.

Title: Stablecoin
Description: Cryptocurrency with a price peg to fiat currencies or commodity.

Title: Staking
Description: The state of locking-in significant amount of token to participate as a validator of a Proof-of-Stake network.

Title: Stale Block
Description: Double mined blocks that are not included in the blockchain.

Title: State Channel
Description: Secondary payment channel occuring off-chain

Title: STO
Description: Security Token Offering (STO) refers to a public offering for tokenized digital securities, or in short security tokens traded in cryptocurrency exchanges.

Title: Stop-loss Order
Description: Conditional market order to sell at the next available price, excuted if the price of an asset falls below set-upon limit

Title: Super Staker
Description: A Qtum Core wallet (full node) providing Proof of Stake for delegated addresses, and keeping a small part of each block reward as their fee for providing the staking services.

Title: Tangle
Description: The name for IOTA's Directed acylic graph (DAG) based transaction settlement layer.

Title: Testnet
Description: Shorthand for "Test Network", testnets are staging areas for experimenting new blockchain features.

Title: Ticker
Description: A ticker is a stock or asset symbol that abbreviates the asset name and it can be used as an identifier of the asset.

Title: Token
Description: Blockchain based unit of value issued by an organization, which grants token holders a right to participate in a network.

Title: Token Burn
Description: An event in which tokens are verifiably removed permanently removed from circulation.

Title: Token Generation Event (TGE)
Description: An event in which new tokens (ussually on a smart contract platform) are created and distributed to the public.

Title: Total Supply
Description: All the tokens and coins that will exist in a cryptocurrency network.

Title: Total Value Locked
Description: Total Value Locked (TVL) represents the number of assets that are currently staked in a protocol or the total quantity of underlying amount of funds that a DeFi protocol has secured.

Title: Trading Volume
Description: The amount of the cryptocurrency that has been traded in the last 24 hours.

Title: Transaction Fee
Description: A payment to the network for performing a transaction to be recorded on the blockchain.

Title: Transactions Per Second (TPS)
Description: It is number of transactions done per second. For example, there are 10 transactions of Bitcoin done in 1-minute. The TPS would be 10 transactions/60 seconds = ~0.17 TPS.

Title: Trustless
Description: Entirely verifiable, without needing to trust or assume an action is done completely and in good faith.

Title: Turing-Complete
Description: A "turing complete" code or blockchain refers to the ability to read program-written codes.

Title: Unspent Transaction Output
Description: (abbv. "UTXO") Coins that are unspent in the wallet. UTXO virtually represents the cryptocurrency one own in the wallet.

Title: UTC Time
Description: Universal Time Coordinated", can be used interchangably with Greenwich Mean Time (GMT).

Title: Utility Token
Description: cryptocurrency tokens with specific utilities on a network besides being used as medium of exchange and investment vehicle.

Title: Validator
Description: A block-signing participant of a Proof of Stake blockchain network, whom have significant tokens staked on the network.

Title: Variable Buy/Sell Tax
Description: On-chain buy sell tax rate that is not fixed, whereby it is possible for contract owners to change at will.

Title: Venture Capital
Description: capital (funds) that is invested in a company that needs a substantial pool of funds to initiate.

Title: Virtual AMM (vAMM)
Description: The vAMM functions similarly like an AMM but does not contain an actual asset pool.

Title: Wallet
Description: Software client that handles storage of cryptocurrencies and allows users to send cryptocurrencies.

Title: Wallet Address
Description: The address in which cryptocurrency can be stored, sent to and receive.

Title: Wash Trade
Description: Meaningless back and forth trading between a single party with the aim of inflating trade volume.

Title: Watchlist
Description: A personally defined list of values to watch over for activity or changes.

Title: Web3 Wallet
Description: Web3 Wallet is the software that allows you to interact with web 3.0.

Title: Wei
Description: The smallest fraction of an Ether, with each Ether to 1000000000000000000 Wei.

Title: Whale
Description: Someone who holds an enormous amount of cryptocurrency and has the ability to wave the market

Title: When Lambo
Description: An expression used by investors to ask when the value of their investment could buy them a Lamborghini

Title: When Moon
Description: An expression used by investors to ask when the price of a coin would hit a peak

Title: Whitelist
Description: List of approved participants that will be given access to a token sale (ICO, IEO, STO etc...)

Title: Whitepaper
Description: An introductory paper to consicely explain an issue and a possible solution on the issue.

Title: Yield Farming
Description: Yield farming involves putting cryptocurrency into a DeFi protocol to collect interest on trading fees.

Title: YTD
Description: Acronym for Year-to-date

Title: Zero Confirmation Transaction
Description: Another name for "unconfirmed transaction

Title: Zero Knowledge Proof
Description: Cryptographic proof for 2 parties to verify a value without revealing what the value is.

Title: Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-Interactive Argument of Knowledge (Zk-Snarks)
Description: An acronym for Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-Interactive Argument of Knowledge, zk-SNARKs refers to a protocol where one can prove posession of a given piece of information (eg a string or hash) without revealing that information and also without any interaction between both the prover & verifier.
